awd_titl_txt: Application Characterization for Adaptive Computing Platform Determination for Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Traditional high performance computing clusters (HPCC) and Hadoop clusters are both important platforms in computational and data-enabled science and engineering (CDS&E). Hadoop MapReduce is typically effective in large-scale data analysis while traditional HPC is more commonly employed in computational problems (petabytes vs. petaflops). HPCC can include a shim layer that allows Hadoop MapReduce to access HPC storage (denoted by Hadoop+HPCC), local storage (denoted by Hadoop), and a combination of both (denoted by Hadoop/HPCC). This project aims to identify the characteristics of various CDS&E MapReduce computational tasks, and adaptively determine the best platform (Hadoop, Hadoop+HPCC and Hadoop/HPCC) for individual applications based on their characteristics, and also optimally arrange data placement between local storage and dedicated remote storage, given performance objectives and system cost metrics. 

Broader impacts include critical insights into the suitability of different computing platforms to different CDS&E applications, and a more advanced HPC system. Research results will be disseminated through technology transfer to industry partners, via publication in peer review journals, and in software releases. Results will also serve as catalyst for research in cyberinfrastructure, which serves the CDS&E fields. This project will provide thorough training of students and collaborative research opportunities for participating Clemson graduates, undergraduates, faculty, and K-12 students. Results will be integrated into courses taught by the PIs. The PIs will recruit new students, particularly those from underrepresented groups, to undertake the study of a STEM discipline.

por.por_cntn:
Traditional high performance computing clusters (HPCC) and Hadoop MapReduce clusters are both important platforms in computational and data-enabled science and engineering (CDS&E). Hadoop MapReduce is typically effective in large-scale data analysis while traditional HPC is more commonly employed in computational problems (petabytes vs petaflops). Architecturally, the two approaches differ in the configuration of storage resources. In the Hadoop Distributed File system (HDFS), data resides on the compute nodes, while in traditional HPC clusters data is stored on separate nodes dedicated to storage. Different applications may benefit from either or both approaches. This project aims to identify the characteristics of various CDS&E MapReduce computational tasks (e.g., computation-intensive, data-intensive, and I/O-intensive), and adaptively determine the best platform (Hadoop, Hadoop+HPCC and Hadoop/HPCC) for individual tasks based on their characteristics, and also optimally arrange data placement between local storage and dedicated storage given performance objectives and system cost metrics. The PIs have undertaken the following tasks: i) Identify the Features of Different CDS&E Applications, 2) Characterize the Impact of Application Features on Performance, and 3) Determine the Optimal Platform for Individual CDS&E Applications.

Broader impacts include critical insights into the suitability of different computing platforms (i.e., HPCC and Hadoop) to different CDS&E applications, and a more advanced HPC system. Research results have been disseminated through peer reviewed conference papers and journals. Results serve as catalyst for research in cyberinfrastructure, which serve the computational and data-enabled science and engineering fields. This project provides thorough training of students,collaborative research opportunities for participating graduates and undergraduates, faculty, and K-12 students. Results are integrated into courses on cloud computing taught by the PIs. The PIs recruited graduate students and undergraduate students.
